Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the next number on my call list. It was Jamie, my best friend, and her voice trembled as she asked if I had a moment. She’d just had a huge fight with her partner, and I could hear the tears she was trying to hold back. My heart twisted—I knew she needed me to listen, to be there for her like I always promised. But I glanced at the clock: only an hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager had already warned me about my numbers, and I couldn’t afford to fall behind again. The headset felt heavy on my head, the script open in front of me, but Jamie’s pain was so real on the other end of the line. I wanted to be the friend she needed, but the pressure to keep my job and meet my quota pressed in on me. My mind raced, torn between the comfort I owed my friend and the responsibility I owed my job, as Jamie waited for my answer.
